lines.text: Enter COUNTESS and Clown

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: It hath happened all as I would have had it, save that he comes not along with her.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: By my troth, I take my young lord to be a very melancholy man.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: By what observance, I pray you

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Why, he will look upon his boot and sing mend the ruff and sing ask questions and sing pick his teeth and sing. I know a man that had this trick of melancholy sold a goodly manor for a song.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Let me see what he writes, and when he means to come.
Opening a letter

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: I have no mind to Isbel since I was at court: our old ling and our Isbels o the country are nothing like your old ling and your Isbels o the court: the brains of my Cupids knocked out, and I begin to love, as an old man loves money, with no stomach.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: What have we here

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Een that you have there.
Exit

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: [Reads]  I have sent you a daughterinlaw: she hath recovered the king, and undone me. I have wedded her, not bedded her and sworn to make the not eternal. You shall hear I am run away: know it before the report come. If there be breadth enough in the world, I will hold a long distance. My duty to you.Your unfortunate son, BERTRAM. This is not well, rash and unbridled boy. To fly the favours of so good a king To pluck his indignation on thy head By the misprising of a maid too virtuous For the contempt of empire.
Reenter Clown

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: O madam, yonder is heavy news within between two soldiers and my young lady!

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: What is the matter

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Nay, there is some comfort in the news, some comfort your son will not be killed so soon as I thought he would.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Why should he be killed

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: So say I, madam, if he run away, as I hear he does: the danger is in standing tot thats the loss of men, though it be the getting of children. Here they come will tell you more: for my part, I only hear your son was run away.
Exit
Enter HELENA, and two Gentlemen

lines.speaker: first gentleman
lines.text: Save you, good madam.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Madam, my lord is gone, for ever gone.

lines.speaker: second gentleman
lines.text: Do not say so.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Think upon patience. Pray you, gentlemen, I have felt so many quirks of joy and grief, That the first face of neither, on the start, Can woman me untot: where is my son, I pray you

lines.speaker: second gentleman
lines.text: Madam, hes gone to serve the duke of Florence: We met him thitherward for thence we came, And, after some dispatch in hand at court, Thither we bend again.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Look on his letter, madam heres my passport. When thou canst get the ring upon my finger which never shall come off, and show me a child begotten of thy body that I am father to, then call me husband: but in such a then I write a never. This is a dreadful sentence.
Reads

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Brought you this letter, gentlemen

lines.speaker: first gentleman
lines.text: Ay, madam And for the contents sake are sorry for our pain.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: I prithee, lady, have a better cheer If thou engrossest all the griefs are thine, Thou robbst me of a moiety: he was my son But I do wash his name out of my blood, And thou art all my child. Towards Florence is he

lines.speaker: second gentleman
lines.text: Ay, madam.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: And to be a soldier

lines.speaker: second gentleman
lines.text: Such is his noble purpose and believe t, The duke will lay upon him all the honour That good convenience claims.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Return you thither

lines.speaker: first gentleman
lines.text: Ay, madam, with the swiftest wing of speed.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: [Reads]  Till I have no wife I have nothing in France. Tis bitter.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Find you that there

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Ay, madam.

lines.speaker: first gentleman
lines.text: Tis but the boldness of his hand, haply, which his heart was not consenting to.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Nothing in France, until he have no wife! Theres nothing here that is too good for him But only she and she deserves a lord That twenty such rude boys might tend upon And call her hourly mistress. Who was with him

lines.speaker: first gentleman
lines.text: A servant only, and a gentleman Which I have sometime known.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Parolles, was it not

lines.speaker: first gentleman
lines.text: Ay, my good lady, he.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: A very tainted fellow, and full of wickedness. My son corrupts a wellderived nature With his inducement.

lines.speaker: first gentleman
lines.text: Indeed, good lady, The fellow has a deal of that too much, Which holds him much to have.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Youre welcome, gentlemen. I will entreat you, when you see my son, To tell him that his sword can never win The honour that he loses: more Ill entreat you Written to bear along.

lines.speaker: second gentleman
lines.text: We serve you, madam, In that and all your worthiest affairs.

lines.speaker: countess
lines.text: Not so, but as we change our courtesies. Will you draw near!
Exeunt COUNTESS and Gentlemen

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Till I have no wife, I have nothing in France. Nothing in France, until he has no wife! Thou shalt have none, Rousillon, none in France Then hast thou all again. Poor lord! ist I That chase thee from thy country and expose Those tender limbs of thine to the event Of the nonesparing war and is it I That drive thee from the sportive court, where thou Wast shot at with fair eyes, to be the mark Of smoky muskets O you leaden messengers, That ride upon the violent speed of fire, Fly with false aim move the stillpeering air, That sings with piercing do not touch my lord. Whoever shoots at him, I set him there Whoever charges on his forward breast, I am the caitiff that do hold him tot And, though I kill him not, I am the cause His death was so effected: better twere I met the ravin lion when he roard With sharp constraint of hunger better twere That all the miseries which nature owes Were mine at once. No, come thou home, Rousillon, Whence honour but of danger wins a scar, As oft it loses all: I will be gone My being here it is that holds thee hence: Shall I stay here to dot  no, no, although The air of paradise did fan the house And angels officed all: I will be gone, That pitiful rumour may report my flight, To consolate thine ear. Come, night end, day! For with the dark, poor thief, Ill steal away.
Exit
